description: {"blocks":[{"key":"6iook","text":"High-throughput detection of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) in complex environmental samples is challenging for two reasons: 1) ARGs account for less than 0.1% of total DNA in an environmental sample, and 2) it is difficult to detect thousands of ARGs in one reaction. Conventional methods, including metagenomic sequencing and quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR), have their limitations with sensitivity and target range, respectively. Here, we propose a multiplexed CRISPR-Cas9-based target-enriched next-generation sequencing (NGS) method to detect thousands of ARGs in complex environmental samples, using sewage as a testbed. This protocol includes guide RNA design, guide RNA synthesis, DNA sample preparation, CRISPR-NGS library preparation, and data processing steps. With this protocol, ARGs in low abundances can be detected with increased read depth and higher sensitivity than regular metagenomic NGS methods. This protocol is also applicable for detecting other low-abundance genetic markers, for example, bacterial virulence factors, in environmental samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6r6c5","text":"Incubate the RNA transcription samples at 37 ℃ for 4 hours.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9j4kp","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3ma82","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8qc4g","text":"A white mist should be visible for a successful reaction after incubation.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8cs88","text":"Add 5 μL of DNase I and 5 μL of DNA Digestion Buffer provided in RNA Clean \u0026 Concentrator-5 (DNase Included) to each 40-μL RNA transcription reaction. Pipette up and down 10 times or until well mixed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"9tg97","text":"Incubate at room temperature for 15 min.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"djopc","text":"Follow the “Total RNA Clean-up” instructions in the user manual of RNA Clean \u0026 Concentrator-5. Use 15 μL of DNase/RNase-Free Water to elute the purified crRNA or tracrRNA product. Incubate for 5 min before the final centrifugation to ensure maximum yield.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ce6oq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c1iel","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"552lf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"31r8","text":"Use 1.5 volumes of ethanol to reach maximum RNA yield as suggested in the manual for 17-200 nt RNA, in the case of 40 μL transcription with 5 μL of DNase I and 5 μL of DNA Digestion Buffer added, use 225 μL of 100% ethanol. Highly recommend using low-retention pipette tips to ensure maximum RNA yield.\n","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5ed72","text":"Pipette each purified crRNA or tracrRNA product up and down for 10 times or until well mixed. Take 1 μL from each purified RNA sample, dilute 100-fold in 99 μL of molecular biology grade water. Pipette up and down for 10 times or until well mixed. Quantify each 100-fold-diluted purified crRNA or tracrRNA using Qubit‱RNA Broad Range (BR) Assay Kit by adding 10 μL diluted sample to 190 μL of master mix.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":317,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"510bj","text":"the","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2dgpa","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"586kt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"emoji","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"0F64C51E7E7811EEBDFB0A58A9FEAC02","name":":tm:"}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"114ea","text":"This is not just a QC step. It is necessary to determine the concentration for each crRNA and tracrRNA for calculating themixing ratio before making duplexed guide RNA. Usually, the final concentrations for crRNA are \u003e2,000 ng/μL, and the final concentrations for tracrRNA are \u003e 4,000 ng/μL.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2vr83","text":"Aliquot the crRNA and tracrRNA samples and store at -80 ℃ before use.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dgfc","text":"Right before making CRISPR-NGS library, mix crRNA and tracrRNA in
anequi-molar ratio (see Equation 1), then add Nuclease-Free Duplex Buffer to
reach a final guide RNA concentration of 1500 ng/μL (see Equation 2). Pipette
up and down 10 times or until well mixed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e4ph4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11ij6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bm6s5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2jh46","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"0BE7DCE3B3D340E99FC0E8BFEBB7497B","height":"38","is_video":false,"legend":"{"blocks":[{"key":"dnd60","text":"Equation 1: crRNA and tracrRNA equi-molar ratio mixing ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":55}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}","mime":null,"nestedSelector":null,"original_name":null,"placeholder":"blob:https://www.protocols.io/4ea84973-ba32-468d-bbbd-bdf760a3524c","shadow":false,"source":"blob:https://www.protocols.io/4ea84973-ba32-468d-bbbd-bdf760a3524c","width":"207"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"D5C59BAF5290472A86A47C65CA838845","height":"40","is_video":false,"legend":"{"blocks":[{"key":"frp4t","text":"Equation 2: Volume calculation for crRNA and tracrRNA mixing ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":61}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}","mime":null,"nestedSelector":null,"original_name":null,"placeholder":"blob:https://www.protocols.io/c22b7471-7d90-44a7-a861-bdaca3abe20f","shadow":false,"source":"blob:https://www.protocols.io/c22b7471-7d90-44a7-a861-bdaca3abe20f","width":"430"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"33ppe","text":"Incubate the mixture in a thermal cycler at 94 ℃ for 2 min, then slowly cool down to room temperature. The guide RNA is ready to use.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: DNA sample preparation (Sewage sample as an example)
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"fvvhl","text":"Shake the sewage sample until well mixed, and filter 50 mL of the sewage sample through\n0.45 μm pore size membrane filter. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"tj8r","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f393d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2jp84","text":"The volume is determined by the turbidity of the sewage sample. steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"a1cpv","text":"Create a Linux environment. It can be set up in MobaXterm (https://mobaxterm.mobatek.net/) or other preferred terminal software. Here, as an example, all available sequences for antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) from The Comprehensive Antibiotic Resistance Database (CARD) (https://card.mcmaster.ca/) were downloaded using the link: https://card.mcmaster.ca/latest/data.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":187,"length":25},{"key":1,"offset":246,"length":36}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B4F8DDAC7E9811EEBDFB0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://card.mcmaster.ca"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B4F8DDAC7E9811EEBDFB0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://card.mcmaster.ca/latest/data"}}}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"foq0j","text":"For an ARG detection project, among all downloaded “.fasta” files, “nucleotide_fasta_protein_homolog_model.fasta” was used as the input, because the ARGs that have raised high concerns such as the CTX-M gene families and the mcr gene families are included in the protein homolog model.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":197,"length":5},{"style":"italic","offset":225,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":109}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fvv8r","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4akku","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"i361","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dbpf","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"59htf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"can_edit":true,"command_name":"","description":"","guid":"A9F6CD987E9A11EEBDFB0A58A9FEAC02","name":"import argparse
import os

parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
parser.add_argument('-i',dest='input',type=str,required=True,help='Define input txt folder')
parser.add_argument('-o',dest='output',type=str,required=True,help="Define output path for a combined txt")
args=parser.parse_args()

full_gRNA_list=[]
dir_path=args.input.strip("'")
dir_list=os.listdir(dir_path)
for file_name in dir_list:
    print('Processing '+file_name+' ......')
    file=open(dir_path+'/'+file_name)
    raw_content=file.readlines()
    file.close()
    for i in range(0,len(raw_content)):
        raw_content[i]=raw_content[i].strip('\t\n\r')
    for i in range(0,len(raw_content),3):
        full_gRNA_list.append(raw_content[i])

full_gRNA_list=list(set(full_gRNA_list))

output_file=open(args.output.strip("'"),"w")
for i in range(0,len(full_gRNA_list)):
    output_file.write(full_gRNA_list[i]+'\n')
output_file.close()

parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
parser.add_argument('-i',dest='input',type=str,required=True,help='Define input txt folder')
parser.add_argument('-o',dest='output',type=str,required=True,help="Define output path for a combined txt")
args=parser.parse_args()

file=open(args.input.strip("'"))
gRNA_list=file.readlines()
file.close()

output_list=sorted(list(set(gRNA_list)))
output_file=open(args.output.strip("'"),'w')
for i in range(0,len(output_list)):
    output_file.write(output_list[i])
output_file.close()
